26/May/2021. tam. This co-occurs with /mo/, /pa/, sometimes /ken/... It's not clear that there is a specific 'negative-imperative'/'vetative' verbal morpheme; it may be a characteristic of the combination of particles in question (/pa=mo/, /ken=mo/ etc.) plus the zero-past. --check! (NB: but I just found an example in which the vetative occurs with a plural marker /-të/; this means it can't be the zero past, which would have /-ti(i)/...)

Note also Marcelino & Otávio (+ Elzirene) saying that /(j)aipï/ is a word for 'support', 'defense', 'help'.

07/Aug/2021. CV-reducing. Vt. Synonyms: /iisika/, /(t)ëu/. But notice you can say /sikë wiisikae/, /sikë wëujae/ 'I remove jiggers', but not */sikë wamiijae/. Maybe 'taking things that are scattered'? Tomas says 'opnemen', i.e. take things that are on the ground; if fruits are on a tree, then you say /wïpëëjae/, but if they have fallen, you say /wamiijae/. (Note: Nimrod had /amiku/, not /amikï/; Wïta agrees with him; and Tomas was in doubt between /amiku/ and /amikï/... --check!). 11/Aug/2017. Vt. How is this verb related to /anu(mu)/, /aanu(ku)/, /ënaanu(ku)/, etc? --check! The meaning 'save' is based on the metaphor of 'falling': if /anotanïhpo/ 'make fall' = 'damn, make go to hell', then /anunnëpï/ 'make rise, raise' = 'save, send to heaven'. (There seems to be some variation: sometimes I get /anunnëpï/, sometimes /anunëpï/; there were cases of /annunopï/, with /o/, or /annunëpï/, with two /n/'s at the first syllable boundary --check!)

11/Aug/2017. Pp. space. Is this the same as /tao/ 'inside'? Apparently, /nonohtao/ 'on the ground' and /nonotao/ 'inside the earth' form a minimal pair. So /tao/ is really 'inside', and /htao/ is more like 'in the area defined by' (cf. also /itu=htao/, /mahto=htao/ (vs. /mahto=tao/)). In Leavitt's bible translation, however, some occurrences of /htao/ are probably wrong -- /tao/ should have occurred instead -- and suggest either confusion, or some real variation, between /htao/ and /tao/ (which, at least in K-Tiriyó, is to be expected).

Parameter_ID: relative; people; kinsman; neighbor; comrade; some; others
Comment: 30/Nov/2021. /-rï/. N. culture social kinship. Notice that it can be used for your co-nationals (a man in Kuwamara told me that 'my /moitï/' were all the Brazilians, and that I wouldn't become a /moitï/ of the Tiriyó just by learning the language-- I'd have to marry one of their women). In Leavitt's bible translation, there are cases of /moitï/ referring to non-human inanimates -- apparently meaning 'some (of)' in this case. Is that really possible? --check! (It would seem /moitï/ refers to 'member(s) of a group', no matter how the group is defined...)

Parameter_ID: offend; gossip; say.evil; badmouth; slander; do.evil; fight; trouble; fiddle.with
Comment: 23/Jun/2021. CV-reducing. Vt. The last syllable was not attested-- I think it is /pï/, by analogy with other /-no(pï)/ verbs (cf. /eiraano(pï)/). Jutesi describes the meaning of /pahko wipëkëënoojae/ as: I say '/kure=ta manae/', '/amïma ëmë/', '/ëewaaje=ta/' to him. Apparently from /pëkë/ 'about, involved with', maybe nominalized with /-no/? Or is this /-nopï/? Anyway, something like 'becoming involved with someone' = 'making trouble for someone'. The derived word /pëkëënoo=me=ta/ seems to have become semantically independent, with a meaning roughly translatable as 'strong, unattackable, hard to deal with'. (NB: there is some evidence that the stem has a long second /ë/: /pëkëëno(pï)/. --check!)

Comment: 11/Aug/2017. A. Looks like /tï/ '3r' + /waarë/ 'known:to'; but, rather than meaning 'known to him/herself', 'self-knowledge', it means 'worried, jealous'; is this sufficient semantic change for a lexicalization analysis? --check!

11/Aug/2017. A. Obviously a /t-/ adverb, with /waku/ 'belly'. The ending /-tuje/ does not seem to be a productive suffix (e.g. */toonatuje/ was not accepted). Could /waku/ really be /wakutu/, and the ending really be /-je/? Apparently not-- João do Vale refused */jiwakutu=npë/, and accepted only /jiwaku=npë/.

11/Aug/2017. A. This looks like /tï-wame(ke)=ta/, where /ta/ could be /ta(ike)/ 'Neg' or /ta(ka)/ 'Dir'. There are other examples with /ta(ike)/ (check /jiwameh=ta/); but /tïwamehta/ has the opposite meaning to what it should have (instead of 'not ignoring oneself', it means 'not knowing, unknowingly'. The meaning is better explained if one assumes the final /ta/ is /ta(ka)/; but then it's difficult to understand how it can co-occur with the copula (/tïwamehta manae/). All in all, it seems better to leave it as a lexicalized unit -- at least for the time being. (Note that the long vowel in /tïwamehtaa=nai/ agrees with the two proposed etymologies here.)
24/Aug/2019. A. Apparently also 'transparent', in the sense that it lets light through.

Comment: 17/Jun/2021. /t/-adding. Vt. Irregular detransitivized form /ëhtë/ (< /ët-wë/). There were also a few cases of /wïhtë/ = /wïwë/ 'I shot it', /kïhtëe/ 'I'll shoot it' --check them! (Otávio confirms /wïhtëe/, /kïhtëe/ as 'old people's language' for /wïwëe/, /kïïwëe/.)  I note that the /ë/ has a tendency to be long in forms where the stem is word initial. Note the reduplicated form in /eemi wëë=wëënenpë/ = the one who shot and shot his daughter. This may indicate underlying length for this vowel -- or also something about lost morphology (i.e. a lost /i-/ or /ï-/ prefix on this stem).

11/Aug/2017. Vt. For bodies of water (rivers, lakes, etc.) Some informants said /:rëtï/. In one example, the missing initial syllable seems to be /pï/ (cf. Ririhpë's story in tirwrtxt.txt). Note also Nasau's /pïrëtënë/, apparently 'crossing', and Renato's /pïrëh-të/ 'good at crossing'.

27/Aug/2019. Vt. body. Apparently, cut the hair very short, or cut it all off. This stem was attested a couple of times as <repitï> in Leavitt's bible translation, but, even there, it occurs more often as <ripitï>.
30/Jul/2017. Pp. space. Probably related to /pïropï/ 'chest'; cf. also /:roowë/ 'in the middle of'. Apparently, there is a 'directional' element /kïi/ and a 'locative' element /wë/.
03/Jun/2002. Vo. /pïro/ + /-kepï/ 'Cessative'.
27/Aug/2019. Vt. Used only for washing manioc roots after pulling them out and peeling them (they're dirty with dirt from people's hands).
30/Jul/2017. Pp. space. Probably related to /pïropï/ 'chest'; cf. also /:rohkïi/ 'to the middle of'
23/Dec/2004. Pp. space. Synonymous with /:rohkïi/.
03/Jun/2002. Pp. space. Obviously, from /pïropï/ 'chest' + /pëe/ 'from'.
03/Jun/2002. Pp. space. /pïropï/ 'chest' + /po/; synonymous with /:roowë/?
03/Jun/2002. Pp. space. /pïropï/ 'chest' + /pona/ 'Dir'.
04/Aug/2021. Vt. I.e., to see/have (e.g., in a dream) a bad omen about O (= someone, something). (Cf. /jaapo/ 'bad omen'.)

30/Jul/2017. incorporation?. Vt. At first sight, /:ro-tëëka/ 'throat-hit'; but this refers to one's feet (stumble)!! Maybe not really a case of incorporation... or does /:ro/ mean something other than 'throat'? --check!
30/Jul/2017. Vt. Intransitive counterpart, /eeseka/. But note that some speakers did not accept the transitive counterpart...
11/Aug/2017. Vt. Is the long /ii/ a consequence of the /s/? --check verbs with this pattern!
irr.conjugation. Vo. This looks like a /-ta/-verb: /suku/ 'urine' + /-ta/ 'verbalizer'.
03/Jun/2002. Vo. Used only of animals: /ooko/, /kurairu/, /marasi/, /kaikui/ (hond).
30/Jul/2017. N. body. The initial lengthening indicates a missing syllable -- check which one!
03/Jun/2002. irr.conjugation. Va. Allomorph /oeka/ with /k-/ '1Sa', /m-/ '2Sa', /n-/ '3Sa' prefixes.
